ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The readings were incredible and gave me a greater worldview. I learned how to analyze a piece and read it critically. My writing also improved a great deal and I finally learned how to write a good essay.
I learned how to critically analyze and contextualize historical movements

Knowledge: A diverse, international perspective on (leftist) revolutions throughout the 20th century. 
Skills: analyzing the rhetoric of speeches, essays, poetry, fiction, artwork, and music; critical and close reading; integrating sources into papers; citation; most importantly, how to write a college paper (of 10 pages length, which was a new experience).
Insights: Although this course primarily discussed the works of leaders/writers with Communist inclinations, the material and subsequent analysis often highlighted the moral flaws in their perspectives.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: syllabus was great, the professor was amazing and super helpful and understanding, the people in the class always were always ready to have a great discussion.
Weaknesses: None besides there was more reading and assignments compared to other English 114 but it was manageable.

The class really gives you a necessary scope for each type of revolution/political movement explored in the course. And, every assignment was clearly explained. No weaknesses whatsoever; I enjoyed every class I went to.

Strengths: Covered a wide range of topics
Weaknesses: Sometimes the readings were lacking historic context

Strengths: 
-Professor Abraham-Fiallos is an excellent teacher and discussion leader. His enthusiasm for the various revolutionary movements permeated and galvanized each class period. He was always open to discussing assignments, such as brainstorming or providing critical feedback. 
-Diversity of material: Without this course, I would have never engaged with a significant majority of the material. The diversity of material discussed provided a very international perspective, not just American or Euro-centric outlook like many HS courses,  on the 20th century and its revolutions. 
-Developing writing skills: For the first time, I was expected to regularly write lengthy papers (5 pages, then 10 pages by the final research paper). Initially, I was terrified of such an endeavor, but the progression of this course smoothed the transition from HS to Yale-level writing, in length and prose style. 
Weaknesses:
-n/a

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: There wasn't many practices geared towards the pandemic but it was such a small class I don't think there needed to be. I liked that the office hours were drop in and not sign up because it's a lot less intimidating and easy to do. Allowing extensions on different assignments really helped as well and took pressure off the class.
Prof did a really great job of engaging us and knowing us on a personal level.
The seminar format transitioned seamlessly to Zoom. Meetings with the professor via Zoom were also very convenient!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes absolutely. It was my favorite course by far and I think everyone should have to take it.
Take this class!! You won't regret it. This is a fantastic introduction to Yale writing.
Yes, this class was a great introduction to college English classes and historical reading.

Certainly! I would highly recommend this course to any student with a love of history and/or politics interested in bolstering their writing & analysis skills. You'll get to explore a diverse range of works, authors, and movements; at least for me, this course removed the cultural stigma surrounding such revolutionary rhetoric, in favor of sharply and mindfully reading pieces critically. Each paper was fascinating to construct, as was the culminating manifesto project. Hopefully, Professor Abraham-Fiallos teaches this course once more, as his leadership provided an excellent learning and growing experience.
